articles.headline: White House Says It Believes Syria Has Used Chemical Arms
articles.snippet: The assessment could test President Obama’s repeated warnings that the use of chemical weapons by President Bashar al-Assad might precipitate American intervention in Syria.
articles.abstract: The assessment could test President Obama’s repeated warnings that the use of chemical weapons by President Bashar al-Assad might precipitate American intervention in Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House said Thursday that it believes the Syrian government has used chemical weapons in its civil war, an assessment that could test President Obama’s repeated warnings that such an attack could precipitate American intervention in Syria.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: From the Fed, a New Chill to Banks From Abroad
articles.snippet: Foreign banks are pushing back against a Federal Reserve proposal to tighten rules on their American subsidiaries.
articles.abstract: Foreign banks are pushing back against a Federal Reserve proposal to tighten rules on their American subsidiaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was a time, not long ago, when bank regulators around the globe trusted one another.

articles.headline: Market Delay in Chicago Points Again to Technology
articles.snippet: The Chicago Board Options Exchange opened after a delay of several hours because of a system failure.
articles.abstract: The Chicago Board Options Exchange opened after a delay of several hours because of a system failure.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Southern Europe’s Recession Threatens to Spread North
articles.snippet: Germany and other nations in Northern Europe could be caught in the recession of Southern Europe, which would slow the continent’s recovery and hinder growth worldwide.
articles.abstract: Germany and other nations in Northern Europe could be caught in the recession of Southern Europe, which would slow the continent’s recovery and hinder growth worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — No company symbolizes German industrial might like Daimler, the giant maker of Mercedes-Benz autos and trucks. So when the company said this week that it, too, had finally been caught in the downdraft of the European economic crisis, it was an ominous sign for all of the Continent, if not the whole world.

articles.headline: Businesses Take a Cautious Approach to Disclosures Using Social Media
articles.snippet: This earnings season, some prominent companies are taking advantage of the S.E.C.’s new rules that allow the use of social media to disclose financial information, though others are proceeding slowly.
articles.abstract: This earnings season, some prominent companies are taking advantage of the S.E.C.’s new rules that allow the use of social media to disclose financial information, though others are proceeding slowly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zynga’s latest quarterly earnings report, released on Wednesday, came in the typical format and was accompanied with the usual financial tables investors expect.
articles.byline: By Michelle Leder and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: U.S. Opens Spigot After Farmers Claim Discrimination
articles.snippet: Government payments to address minority farmers’ claims of discrimination by the Agriculture Department have ballooned amid signs of fraud.
articles.abstract: Government payments to address minority farmers’ claims of discrimination by the Agriculture Department have ballooned amid signs of fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the winter of 2010, after a decade of defending the government against bias claims by Hispanic and female farmers, Justice Department lawyers seemed to have victory within their grasp.

articles.headline: Millionaires Clash Over Socialite’s Child Support Claims
articles.snippet: A Wall Street financier claims that his former lover’s current partner aided her in hiding her true wealth before a Hong Kong court proceeding.
articles.abstract: A Wall Street financier claims that his former lover’s current partner aided her in hiding her true wealth before a Hong Kong court proceeding.
articles.lead_paragraph: As an accomplished mountaineer who has scaled many of the world’s highest peaks, including Mount Everest, Annabelle Bond has found herself in some dicey situations.

articles.headline: Judging ‘Gatsby’ by Its Cover(s)
articles.snippet: The F. Scott Fitzgerald novel, which is selling briskly, now comes with two covers: one based on the original art, and another that is a tie-in to the coming movie.
articles.abstract: The F. Scott Fitzgerald novel, which is selling briskly, now comes with two covers: one based on the original art, and another that is a tie-in to the coming movie.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The Great Gatsby” has united generations of American readers with its crash-and-burn tale of empty elegance and impossible love on Long Island in the 1920s.

articles.headline: Federal Cuts Are Concern in Modest U.S. Growth
articles.snippet: A growth rate of 2.5 percent in the first quarter was most likely a result of unusually slow growth at the end of 2012, when the economy grew at an annual pace of just 0.4 percent.
articles.abstract: A growth rate of 2.5 percent in the first quarter was most likely a result of unusually slow growth at the end of 2012, when the economy grew at an annual pace of just 0.4 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not great, but it’s still probably the best growth the American economy is going to see for a while.

articles.headline: Japan Approves Return to Air of Boeing 787
articles.snippet: The authorities approved fixes to the planes’ batteries and  authorized All Nippon Airways and Japan Airlines, which own about half of the 50 Dreamliners delivered, to resume flights.
articles.abstract: The authorities approved fixes to the planes’ batteries and  authorized All Nippon Airways and Japan Airlines, which own about half of the 50 Dreamliners delivered, to resume flights.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese and American authorities have lifted the final hurdles to the Boeing 787’s return to commercial flights, more than three months after the plane’s battery problems grounded the fleet.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Netflix Looks Back on Its Near-Death Spiral
articles.snippet: Reed Hastings, the video streaming giant’s chief executive, offered a rare public comment on his company’s 2011 Qwikster debacle, which nearly destroyed it, and its improbable rebound.
articles.abstract: Reed Hastings, the video streaming giant’s chief executive, offered a rare public comment on his company’s 2011 Qwikster debacle, which nearly destroyed it, and its improbable rebound.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix, the worst part of the company’s 2011 self-inflicted Qwikster debacle, in which Netflix tried to both raise prices and spin off its DVD-by-mail business, wasn’t the parody by “Saturday Night Live,” the scathing media criticism or even the dizzying plunge in the company’s stock price from almost $299 in July 2011 to about $53 last September.
